newsitem.title: INDIA: Bombay blue-chips end higher, Reliance rallies.
newsitem.headline: Bombay blue-chips end higher, Reliance rallies.

text.p: Bombay share prices closed modestly higher on Friday after positive results by market major Reliance pushed up prices, traders said.
The petrochemical major beat analysts lower profits forecast for the six months to September 30, 1996/97 (April-March), by posting a three percent rise in net profit.
The 30-share index of the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) staged a small rally at close to end 18.88 points or 0.61 points higher to a provisional 3,130.90.
Share of Reliance rose 2.0 rupees to 196.75 on volumes of over 4.9 million shares at the BSE.
The company reported a net profit of 6.51 billion rupees against its year-ago figure of 6.33 billion rupees.
Analysts were expecting higher costs, lower product prices and flat volume growth to supress its profits by 20-25 percent.
"Everybody is actually baffled," said Jal Irani, analyst at Jardine Fleming Broking India. "I am surprised," said analyst Prakash Joshi at W.I.Carr (Far East) in Bombay.
But, they said the firm's decision not to provide for a 12.9 percent minimum tax imposed in India's July federal budget on non-tax paying companies partly explained its good results.
The 50-stock National Stock Exchange index gained 4.74 points or 0.53 percent to a provisional close of 896.74.
ABB dropped 17.50 or 2.28 percent o 749.50 after a bonus issue announcement fell short of market expectations.
The firm on Thursday announced a bonus equity issue of one share for every three shares held.
Dealers said purchases of SBI by UTI, the country's largest mutual fund, helped the stock record gains.
SBI rose 8.75 to 208.75, TELCO 1.75 to 422.0, Bajaj Auto 12.450 to 939.0 and Hind Lever 11.0 to 805.25.
The BSE will be closed on Monday due to a Hindu holiday.
